awd_titl_txt: A National Longitudinal Study of Community Trauma Exposure
awd_abstract_narration:
Community-based traumas are pandemic and recurring, profoundly taxing individual well-being and societal resources. Yet surprisingly few studies have considered how cumulative exposure to collective and individual stressors may contribute to patterns of adjustment over time. Effects of community traumas can span physical boundaries as well as temporal boundaries, with widespread media coverage transmitting a trauma's impact far beyond the directly exposed population, and challenging the traditional view of trauma exposure. Designing and implementing research on collective traumas requires overcoming formidable scientific and logistical challenges resulting from the fundamental unpredictability of these events. Previous studies that have examined adjustment to community traumas usually involve recalling events long after it occurred, making it difficult to disambiguate the effects of trauma on subsequent adjustment. To be able to draw more solid conclusions about long-term trauma reactions requires having a large sample in which information about pre-event mental and physical health, and baseline assessments of psychological responses have been collected during the acute period of trauma response. The proposed work provides such an opportunity by leveraging the investigators' previous research following a large representative sample for which health and trauma exposure was collected. As a result, the proposed work provides a remarkable opportunity to examine how individuals respond over an extended period of time to repeated direct and indirect exposure to terrorism and other individual and collective traumas.

Previous work by the investigators involved conducting a large, nationally representative longitudinal study (including oversampling of Boston and New York areas) in which individuals were surveyed immediately after a traumatic collective trauma, the Boston Marathon Bombings (BMB), and at two additional times, on the 6- and 12-month anniversaries of the BMB. The proposed work provides a unique opportunity to collect two additional waves of data on this sample in order to track ongoing direct and indirect exposure to individual and collective stressors, and their role in adjustment, over time. The research has three primary aims: 1) To investigate prospectively how different types of trauma exposure (i.e., direct vs. indirect media-based) are associated with patterns of long-term adjustment after collective stress (e.g., the BMB); 2) To investigate whether cumulative exposure to prior individual or collective traumas sensitizes individuals to or inoculates them against the negative consequences of subsequent events; and 3) To investigate prospectively the extent to which post-BMB trauma exposure (e.g., direct, indirect, individual, collective) explains predicted associations between acute BMB-related stress response and adjustment over time.  This research will advance knowledge of how individuals cope with collective traumas and highly stressful events, furthering understanding of the unique needs of individuals traumatized by terrorism, both directly, and indirectly, via exposure to media coverage. Such work will provide information to help identify those at risk for subsequent difficulties following major traumatic events. Moreover, the work has important implications for informing the theory and practice of preparing people for collective traumas and helping them cope with the aftermath. These findings will also add to the foundation of knowledge for helping policymakers, service providers, and community leaders design educational and intervention efforts that are cost-effective and sensitive to the needs of the populace.

por.por_cntn:
Community-based traumas are ubiquitous and recurring, profoundly taxing individual well-being and societal resources. Yet surprisingly few studies have considered how cumulative exposure to collective and individual stressors may contribute to adjustment over time. Moreover, widespread media coverage extends the boundaries of local disasters, transmitting their impact far beyond the directly exposed population and challenging traditional views of trauma exposure. Unfortunately, to design and implement research on collective traumas requires overcoming formidable scientific and logistical challenges resulting from the fundamental unpredictability of these events. Consequently, most studies have no information about respondent pre-event mental and physical health, making it difficult to tease apart the effects of trauma on subsequent adjustment. Most studies also do not collect information on psychological responses immediately after the event, making it impossible to accurately evaluate trajectories of adjustment over time. The lack of large population-based samples also precludes comparisons of responses across demographic groups.

This study addressed these gaps by systematically following a nationally representative U.S. sample (N=4,675) that included representative oversamples of residents from metropolitan Boston (n=846) and New York (n=941). Respondents completed online surveys at 2-4 weeks, 6 months (N=3,588), 12 months (N=3260), 18 months (during Ebola public health crisis) (N=3447), 2 years (N=3341), and approximately 3 years after the Boston Marathon bombings (BMB; N=3199; within one week after the Pulse Nightclub shooting in Orlando, Florida). Several additional waves of data collection were conducted among a subsample of respondents that focused on responses to the 2017 and 2018 hurricane seasons. Research participants were from the GfK KnowledgePanel, a nationally representative probability-based panel previously recruited for online data collection.

At each wave, respondents completed assessments of acute or posttraumatic stress responses, direct and indirect media-based exposure to collective traumas and their aftermath, and lifetime exposure to other personally experienced stressors and/or large collective traumas (e.g., mass violence events, infectious disease outbreaks, and natural disasters).

Key findings:

  • Acute stress symptoms steadily increased as daily media-based exposure to BMB-related content increased in the week after the BMB. People who consumed several hours (6 or more) of media following the bombings exhibited more acute stress than people who had actually been at the site of the bombings or had a friend or loved one there.
  • What people saw in the media mattered as well. Greater exposure to graphic (e.g., bloody) images of the BMB was associated with more distress and worry, and poorer functioning in both the early aftermath and later.
  • People who consumed more bombing-related media following the BMB reported more posttraumatic stress symptoms and fear of future negative events over time, and they were then more likely to consume more media following the Pulse Nightclub massacre three years later. The more individuals consumed media after the Pulse Nightclub massacre, the more distress they reported in response to that mass violence event. Thus, the link between trauma-related media exposure and distress appears to be cyclical: Extensive consumption of trauma-related media following collective traumas may sensitize individuals to future trauma-related media coverage and may promote distress following subsequent traumas.
  • Fear of terrorism and having a history of violent victimization appears to draw individuals to graphic coverage of violence, such as videos of beheadings. Choosing to watch a terrorist-perpetrated beheading video was prospectively associated with distress and fear of the future years later. This suggests that exposure to video coverage of violent acts of terror might serve to exacerbate fears about terrorism.
  • Direct and media-based exposure to prior community traumas increases the risk of experiencing stress-related symptoms following a subsequent community trauma. In fact, both the type and timing of prior negative life experiences may affect how people respond to subsequent collective traumas. Prior trauma may sensitize negative responses to collective trauma and recent stressors may exacerbate effects.

Our program of research has advanced conceptual work on coping with collective traumas and highly stressful events over the life course. Our innovative conceptualization of trauma exposure has extended prior work by demonstrating how broadcast and social media coverage of collective traumas contributes to symptom development in populations living beyond directly-affected areas. Our findings join a growing body of research suggesting that the psychological impact of collective traumas is not limited to those directly exposed to trauma. Psychological responses are not explained simply by the degree of trauma exposure or loss; rather, the media is a conduit through which the psychological impact of collective traumas is dispersed beyond directly-affected communities. This important information has not previously been demonstrated using nationally or regionally representative samples and longitudinal research designs. These findings can be used to alert policymakers, clinicians, service providers, educators, and the larger community about the critical role media plays following community-wide traumas. Results can also inform the design of educational materials and intervention efforts that are evidence-based and sensitive to the needs of the public.
